newsitem.title: USA: Two bills offered to ease U.S. encryption exports.
newsitem.headline: Two bills offered to ease U.S. encryption exports.

text.p: Legislators introduced two bills on Thursday to overturn the Clinton administration's export limits on computer encryption technology, a key component of online commerce and global communications.
Encryption products, which scramble information and render it unreadable without a password or software "key," were once the realm of spies and generals.

But with the booming growth of the Internet, secret coding is now used for everything from keeping a business's E-mail confidential to protecting a consumer's credit card number if it is trasmitted online.
Senators said export restrictions on encryption devices were hindering the development of the Internet and made it impossible for U.S. firms to compete with foreign companies.

The bills "roll-back current restrictions on the export of strong cryptography so that high-tech U.S. firms are free to compete in the global marketplace and meet the demand of customers," Sen Pat Leahy, co-sponsor of both bills, said at a Capitol Hill news conference.
"Online commerce will never reach its full potential under the policies of this and past administrations," Sen Conrad Burns, also a co-sponsor, said.

The bills would generally allow a U.S. company to export a product with strong encryption features if similiar products were being offered for sale by a foreign supplier. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, and Burns, Republican of Montanta, introduced similiar measures in the last Congress.
The government would still be permitted to restrict the export of encryption for military use or to countries posing terrorist threats.
The bills would write into law the current policy permitting unrestricted domestic use of encryption but one bill would criminalize the use of codes to obstruct justice.

"Both bills promote the freedom of this nation's fastest growing industry to provide customers here and abroad with products they demand," Robert Holleyman, president of the Business Software Alliance said. The group includes Microsoft Corp, International Business Machines' Lotus Development and Apple Computer, among others.

"This is the most important privacy legislation before the Congress today," Jerry Berman, executive director of the Center for Democracy and Technology, said. Strongly opposed to mandatory key recovery, Berman said the policy ought to be "my lock, my key."
The Clinton administration, which says key recovery is needed so the government can catch international criminals and terrorists, signaled its displeasure with the new bills.

"We continue to be disappointed with Senator Burns' approach because it does not balance the needs of individual privacy and economic growth with national security and public safety," Under Secretary of Commerce William Reinsch said Thursday. "We believe there is a market for key recovery products from businesses who recognize the need for a backdoor to their own corporate data."
